hotspots.label: Lichen (White Patches)
hotspots.fact: Those white and green patches on the rock are living organisms called lichen that help break down the rock over many years. This is called **weathering** â€” that's when rocks slowly break apart into smaller pieces due to wind, water, and living things. Lichen shows us how Earth's surface is always changing!

vocabulary.definition: The slow breaking down of rocks into smaller pieces by wind, water, ice, and living things over time.

hotspots.label: Green Moss Growth
hotspots.fact: The green moss growing on this rock shows that plants can live almost anywhere on Earth, even on hard rocks! Plants like moss need water, air, and sunlight to grow, and this shady forest spot provides all three. This tells us how different organisms interact with their environment.

vocabulary.definition: Any living thing, like a plant, animal, or tiny moss, that needs food, water, and air to survive.

hotspots.label: Brown Rock Material
hotspots.fact: This rock is made of minerals and particles that came from other rocks that broke apart long ago. Rocks are one of the main materials that make up Earth's surface, and they can last for millions of years! Understanding rocks helps us learn about Earth's history.

vocabulary.definition: A hard, solid material made up of minerals that is found in Earth's crust and helps form mountains, hills, and the ground we walk on.

hotspots.label: Green Grass Sprouting
hotspots.fact: The grass growing right next to the rock shows how soil forms and how plants and rocks are connected in nature. As rocks break down into tiny pieces over time, they mix with dead plants to create soil that new plants can grow in. This cycle helps Earth stay alive and healthy!

vocabulary.definition: A mixture of broken-down rock pieces, dead plants, water, and air that plants need to grow.
